image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers holds a copy of the 2023-24 federal budget strategy and outlook book in front of the media

items.synopsis: These major budget measures reveal the type of plan the federal government has for Australia, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: What's in the budget? Here are some of the major measures we know about

image.altText: A girl, Alyssa, whose face is blurred, leans on a car in a relaxed way.

items.synopsis: Child safety departments knowingly leave some children with carers who have had serious concerns raised about them, insiders say. In some states, foster and kinship carers don't even have a working with children check.

title.children: Alyssa grew up in an affluent suburb. She knows people don't see what's 'behind closed doors'

image.altText: People in masks walk past a Westpac building in a city.

items.synopsis: Months after postponing the closures because of an ongoing Senate inquiry, the bank has announced that branches in several states will remain open indefinitely.

title.children: Westpac reverses decision to close eight regional branches

image.altText: Budget tree

items.synopsis: If the federal government's forecast is realised, Jim Chalmers would be the first treasurer to deliver a surplus since Peter Costello.

title.children: Federal budget to forecast first surplus in 15 years

image.altText: A composite of Mariah Carey smiling and Jason Alexander smiling.

items.synopsis: For a generation of people in both Australia and the US, the name Jenny Craig was synonymous with weight loss. But now it's closing shop in the US as some experts fear where diet culture is headed from here.

title.children: 'I feel guilty about the message I put out': The rise and fall of Jenny Craig's US weight loss empire

image.altText: A close up of Dame Edna complete with her iconic sunglasses and purple hair.

items.synopsis: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews confirms Barry Humphries's family has chosen Sydney as the city for the entertainer's service, despite him being born in Melbourne.

title.children: Barry Humphries to be farewelled in Sydney instead of home city Melbourne

image.altText: A man sits at a desk and signs a paper

items.synopsis: The owner of a high-end jeweller in Sydney's CBD is charged with defrauding an insurance company after he allegedly orchestrated his own store's robbery at knifepoint.

title.children: Famous jeweller masterminded robbery on his own Sydney store, police allege

image.altText: John Farnham singing into a microphone.

items.synopsis: The 73-year-old was taken to hospital in March with a respiratory infection, and has been recovering from surgery to treat cancer.

title.children: Singer John Farnham makes 'full recovery' from chest infection that left him hospitalised

image.altText: You view rectilinear windows with red borders across three storeys on a modernist public housing tower.

items.synopsis: Residents of public housing towers in Flemington and North Melbourne launched a class action against the government over the sudden lockdown in July 2020.

title.children: Victorian government offers $5 million settlement over housing tower COVID-19 lockdown

image.altText: Brittany Higgins walking into the ACT court with her head down.

items.synopsis: Confidential documents are released by the inquiry into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann over the alleged rape of Brittany Higgins, detailing concerns investigators had about the case.

title.children: ACT top prosecutor says police report could have been 'crushing' for Brittany Higgins

image.altText: A man sitting in a wheelchair with another man pushing him.

items.synopsis: One of South Australia's most notorious criminals, Domenic Perre, has died less than a year after being found guilty of the deadly 1994 NCA parcel bombing that killed a detective.

title.children: NCA bomber Domenic Perre dies three decades after killing detective

image.altText: Jim Chalmers holds a thick book with a dark blue cover which a lighter blue Southern Cross titled Budget 2023-24

items.synopsis: While the federal government has already announced several measures ahead of the big moment on Tuesday night, the full details don't drop until then. Here's a quick guide to get you up to speed with what's happening and what to watch out for.

title.children: What time is the federal budget announced? And what does 'budget surplus' mean?

image.altText: Black and white photo of Victoria Cafasso wearing a striped Donald and Daisy Duck top.

items.synopsis: New forensic technology will be used to re-examine all Tasmanian cold cases, with police hoping it could finally provide answers to families and loved ones of those like Victoria, whose killer has never been found.

title.children: Hope that killers will be found when all of Tasmania's cold cases are run through new DNA machine

image.altText: An old image of Heather Winchester and her husband John.

items.synopsis: A Hunter Valley woman has told an inquest her Jehovah's Witness mother was acting on what the church wanted her to do by refusing a blood transfusion that could have saved her life.

title.children: Woman tells inquest her Jehovah's Witness mother refused potentially life-saving blood transfusion

image.altText: Man with Ukraine flag patch on uniform in foreground with damaged apartment building in background

items.synopsis: Russia fires 60 Iranian-made kamikaze drones, including 36 at Kyiv — all of which are shot down — as the Kremlin enacts a major security clampdown ahead of annual May 9 Victory Day celebrations.

title.children: Russia launches swarm of kamikaze drones at Ukraine, cancels some annual Victory Day parades

image.altText: A woman checks her mobile phone as she walks past Telstra signage

items.synopsis: Telstra says some of its mobile customers are still having trouble making phone calls, after an earlier outage which affected mobile networks in NSW and Queensland.

title.children: Telstra says outages in NSW and Queensland weren't caused by cyber attack

image.altText: Valery Gerasimov sits at a desk wearing military uniform.

items.synopsis: In authoritarian regimes, competent soldiers are less important than loyal ones. And, as Russia's General Valery Gerasimov may find out in the future, they also make excellent scapegoats for tyrants wishing to save their own skin, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Why this Russian general may be Ukraine's greatest asset

image.altText: An elderly man holds a walker and stands on a balcony in front of the ocean.

items.synopsis: When lifesaver David Winner drowned, four of the 10 people who resuscitated him had learned their CPR skills from him. Now he's on a mission to teach one million Australians the skills that saved his life.

title.children: 'I passed away that day': Now David wants to teach CPR to a million people for free

image.altText: A white ute lies on its side after a crash with its undercarriage visible and a wrecked motorbike lies in front of the vehicle.

items.synopsis: A driver and motorcyclist are dead after a collision at an intersection in Secret Harbour in Perth's south, with a four-year-old boy and 12-year-old girl treated in hospital for minor injuries.

title.children: Ute left overturned near motorbike in mangled wreck as crash kills two men and injures children

image.altText: A shark with a fish in its mouth.

items.synopsis: Fishers say they're losing more and more fish to sharks. While some are calling for increased fishing quotas or culls, researchers say there's no simple answer.

title.children: 'I lost 125 fish to sharks': Anglers say they're encountering more sharks than ever. So what do the numbers tell us?

image.altText: Two Australian Shoveler Ducks on the water in Tasmania

items.synopsis: Duck hunters say there is confusion about changes to bag limits and protected species classifications as they are turned away from Victoria's Lake Buloke.

title.children: Duck shooting banned at popular lake due to alleged illegal hunting

image.altText: An image of a large succulent plant that has big spikes.

items.synopsis: A shire moves to eradicate a popular, waterwise garden plant from public spaces saying its dangerous, skin-piercing spikes and poisonous sap are a risk to human, pet, and native animal safety.

title.children: 'Can pierce to the bone': Shire to eradicate popular garden staple Agave americana due to safety

image.altText: A vehicle drives across a polar landscape as a plane flies overhead

items.synopsis: Experts believe knowledge sharing and collaboration between countries and research organisations are the best ways to prevent the outbreak of future pandemics.

title.children: A 50,000-year-old virus was found frozen in ice last year. Researchers don't know what could happen if it spread

image.altText: A wrecked white vehicle among trees

items.synopsis: The driver of the car is under police guard in hospital after a fatal crash near Flynn overnight.

title.children: Passenger dies and child seriously injured in east Victorian crash

image.altText: A woman points her finger.

items.synopsis: With an expected $4 billion budget surplus, the government comes under fire from Tasmanian senator Jacqui Lambie for withholding spending on Australia's most vulnerable.

title.children: 'Done nothing': Lambie attacks government ahead of expected budget surplus

image.altText: A close-up of the Qantas logo on the tail of one of its planes. The sky behind it is clear.

items.synopsis: The long-running battle between Qantas and the Transport Workers' Union over the sacking of 1,700 ground staff at the height of the pandemic moves to the High Court in Canberra.

title.children: High Court to hear battle between Qantas and Transport Workers' Union over ground crew outsourcing

image.altText: A man in water gear stands on a wooden jetty with a paddle board behind him and an oar in his hands.

items.synopsis: In a "hair-brained" journey of more than 2,500km down the Murray River on just his stand-up paddleboard, Peter Charlesworth's aim is for regional Australians to take their heart health seriously.

title.children: Peter is paddling an epic 2,642km, with no support crew, on a board he's meaningfully named 'Karina'

image.altText: A pro-China supporter holds a Chinese national flag.

items.synopsis: Canada expels Toronto-based Chinese diplomat Zhao Wei after an intelligence report accuses him of trying to target Canadian Shadow Foreign Minister Michael Chong, who has been critical of China's treatment of its Uyghur Muslim minority, and who says Canada should consider joining AUKUS.

title.children: China vows to 'resolutely take countermeasures' after diplomat expelled from Canada

image.altText: Michael matthews celebrates with his arms outstretches

items.synopsis: Michael Matthews earns his first race win since the 2022 Tour de France with a dominant uphill sprint, beating fellow Australian Kaden Groves back into third place at the Giro d'Italia.

title.children: Aussie rider accepts role in stage two crash as Matthews claims memorable victory

image.altText: Two men with backs to the camera lean up against fence looking at cattle

items.synopsis: There's dust in the air, dirt on the boots, and the booming voices of auctioneers break through the cattle-dung-scented air, but farmers don't want to let go of saleyards despite the boom in online sales.

title.children: Social power of saleyards 'like a men's shed, but not just for men'

image.altText: A smiling woman.

items.synopsis: Marisa Batti has had dermal filler injections since she turned 18. But after filler blocked a blood vessel, she wants other people to be aware of the risks.

title.children: This popular cosmetic injection procedure is linked to 12 reports of blindness

image.altText: A close-up photograph of Joon Seong Tan, who is looking at the camera with a neutral expression.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors allege Joon Seong Tan murdered Ju "Kelly" Zhang, a woman he'd dated for a few weeks, later using his phone to search the term: "How many years for killing a person in Australia?"

title.children: Jealous man killed Melbourne mother and disposed of body in bin, court told

image.altText: A woman blows a young child's nose.

items.synopsis: Ash and her young daughter Clancy caught influenza after they forgot to get vaccinated last year. She never wants to experience it again. So why are so many Aussie kids not getting their flu shot?

title.children: Australia is having a bad flu season and vaccination rates are falling

image.altText: CBA image

items.synopsis: The ASX is in the red ahead of tonight's federal budget, and Commonwealth Bank shares fall despite a better-than-expected quarterly profit as the CEO warns of tough times ahead. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX edges lower ahead of federal budget, CBA shares fall as bank says rate hikes hurting customers

schema.headline: Live: ASX edges lower ahead of federal budget, CBA shares fall as bank says rate hikes hurting customers

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Household spending falls
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Commonwealth Bank's Household Spending Intentions survey fell 4.3 per cent in April, but that was partly because of fewer trading days because of the Easter and Anzac Day holidays. The CBA says the index was led lower by reduced spending in home buying, health and fitness, transport, and household services. Higher energy bills saw spending on utilities continue to climb, up by 7 per cent from April last year, the fastest since 2018. CBA chief economist Stephen Halmarick says household spending is being hit by the higher cost of borrowing, with annual spending rates edging down. "With the RBA increasing interest rates again in early May to 3.85 per cent we consider monetary policy to be highly restrictive," Mr Halmarick said. "We continue to expect the lagged effect of higher interest rates to see household spending weaken as the year progresses."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Household spending growth slows
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The higher cost of living is hurting hip pockets. The Bureau of Statistics says consumers are cutting back, with the annual pace of household spending slowing down. Household spending rose 8.2 per cent over the year to March with spending increasing for both goods and services. It rose by nearly 12 per cent in February from a year ago, which was the weakest annual growth since March last year. The March increase was driven by spending on hotels, cafes and restaurants, which saw a 23 per cent increase in spending, and a 16 per cent rise in transport costs. ABS head of business indicators Robert Ewing said inflation was making prices more expensive and therefore increasing spending. "Rising prices are contributing to this growth," he said. "Services price inflation rose 6.1 per cent - it's largest rise since 2001 - and goods price inflation rose 7.6 per cent (over the year to March)."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: CBA ends cashbacks for mortgage customers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In a sign of the profit margin pressure from fierce competition among the big banks for mortgage borrowers, the Commonwealth Bank will stop offering $2000 cashbacks to new home loan customers. The other big banks have also been offering thousands of dollars in cashbacks to new mortgage borrowers, including those who are switching lenders for a better deal (refinancing). But the banks are starting to cut back on the deals with the CBA ceasing its offer from June 1. In addition, RateCity says over the past couple of months, CBA and the other big banks have been reducing discounts for new mortgage customers, including raising rates above Reserve Bank increases. "Cashback deals have become a hot potato for the banks, with CBA the first of the big four to drop them this year," said RateCity research director Sally Tindall. "The big banks have been at the centre of the refinancing storm over the last 12 months, throwing down competitive new customer discounts and cold hard cash to tempt borrowers to switch." "Now they are looking to take shelter from it." "The other big banks could well fold on their cashback deals in coming months, but if they're looking for growth, they've just been handed a reason to keep these deals on the table."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Qantas outsourcing battle before High Court
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: A battle between Qantas and the Transport Workers Union is being played out in the High Court in Canberra today over the outsourcing of 1700 ground staff. Qantas is appealing a ruling that found outsourcing ground crew jobs during the pandemic was illegal. The Federal Court has twice ruled in favour of the Transport Workers Union, who say the outsourcing decision breached the Fair Work Act. Qantas has told the High Court that it gave the union and workers the chance to come up with an alternative plan, but their proposed savings were dwarfed by the $100 million that outsourcing would achieve. The airline also said its decision was made at a time where workers had "less muscle" for industrial action because they weren't working. The Transport Workers Union told reporters today that half of the 1700 ground staff sacked by Qantas in 2020 are yet to find meaningful work, while a third are suffering mental distress. TWU national secretary, Michael Kaine, says Qantas should be compensating workers, instead of "spending eye watering amounts in legal warfare." "The Transport Workers Union, and we understand the Minister for Industrial Relations, will ask the court to dismiss the case." "In essence, we'll be saying that the Fair Work Act is designed to protect workers, allow them to exercise their workplace rights, not give companies like Qantas open slather to sack workers." Here's the background from High Court reporter Elizabeth Byrne.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: NT forecasts budget surplus by 2026
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Northern Territory treasurer Eva Lawler has handed down the 2023 budget, predicting the territory will be back in surplus by the 2026-27 financial year. Spending on infrastructure is the big ticket item, with a record $2.1 billion spend next financial year, mainly on transport. The budget doesn't factor in potential revenue from big projects like fracking, which have not been given the green light. However, the forecast surplus relies on major projects going ahead, in particular, Santos' controversial Barossa gas project in the Timor Sea, which is being challenged by traditional owners. Here's more from the ABC's Matt Garrick.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Markets snapshot at 12:30pm AEST
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX 200: down 0.3% to 7,253 All Ordinaries: down 0.3% to 7,447 Australian dollar: steady at 67.81 US cents Nikkei 225: up 0.8% to 29,168 Dow Jones: down 0.2% to 33,619 S & P 500: flat at 4,138 Nasdaq Composite: up 0.2% to 12,257 FTSE: up 1% to 7,778 DAX: down 0.05% to 15,953 CAC 40: up 0.1% to 7,441 Spot gold: up 0.1% to $US2,023.36 an ounce Brent crude: down 0.4% to $US76.70 a barrel Bitcoin: up 0.3% to $US27,641

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Market in the red over lunchtime
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's a quiet day on the markets ahead of tonight's federal budget. The ASX 200 index is down one quarter of a percentage point to 7,259 with nearly all sectors in the red. Financial stocks have recovered lost ground with the financials index slightly higher. The Commonwealth Bank -0.15 per cent) has come off its early lows after reporting a rise in quarterly profit, but warning of tougher times ahead because higher interest rates. Biotech Imugene (+6.5 per cent) is the best performer, while gold miner Silver Lake Resources (-4.7 per cent) is the worst performer on the ASX 200 index.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Retail sales volumes fall over March quarter
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: There's more signs of the strain that higher interest rates are putting on households, with people buying less but paying higher prices. The latest quarterly data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics shows that retail sales volumes fell 0.6 per cent over the first few months of the year to $96.17 billion, following a 0.3 per cent fall over the December quarter. ABS head of retail statistics Ben Dorber says retail sales volumes dropped as the higher cost of living pressures weighed on household spending. “Outside of the COVID-19 pandemic period, this is the largest fall in retail sales volumes since the September quarter 2009,” Mr Dorber said. "Retail prices rose for the sixth straight quarter, but price growth this quarter is the smallest since September 2021." That was because of discounts on clothing and large household items like furniture and electronic goods. Food prices went up, and sales at cafes, restaurants, and takeaway food services rose, boosted by the return of cultural and sporting events.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The 'drover's dog' and the budget surplus
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you think those comments from shadow treasurer Angus Taylor that a "drover's dog" could have delivered a budget surplus this year sound familiar, you would be right. They were used by then opposition leader Bill Hayden during a Labor Party leadership spill in February 1983. Mr Hayden resigned as party leader and then shadow industrial relations minister Bob Hawke was elected as leader. Afterwards Mr Hayden said "a drover's dog could lead the Labor Party to victory, the way the country is." The Labor party won the election and Mr Hawke became prime minister. So Mr Taylor's inspiration comes from the Labor Party! Here's more on the budget and the "drover's dog" from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX movers and shakers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here are the sectors and companies moving the ASX 200 this morning as investors await tonight's federal budget. Most industry sectors are in the red with the falls led by real estate, energy and industrial firms. The Commonwealth Bank has lost 0.7 per cent after delivering a better than expected quarterly net profit of $2.6 billion as the chief executive Matt Comyn warned that "many of our customers are feeling the strain of higher interest rates and the rising cost of living." Biotech Imugene (+4.4 per cent) is the best performer in the ASX 200, while farm business Elders (-4.6 per cent) is the worst performer.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Telstra outage fixed
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Telstra says the problems facing millions of customers trying to make mobile phone calls has now been fixed. Most people affected were in New South Wales and Queensland but triple zero calls and mobile data weren't impacted. The outage began late last night and Telstra has apologised to customers for any inconvenience.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Markets snapshot at 11:30am AEST
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX 200: down 0.26% to 7,258 All Ordinaries: down 0.3% to 7,452 Australian dollar: down 0.03% at 67.80 US cents Dow Jones: down 0.2% to 33,619 S & P 500: flat at 4,138 Nasdaq Composite: up 0.2% to 12,257 FTSE: up 1% to 7,778 DAX: down 0.05% to 15,953 CAC 40: up 0.1% to 7,441 Spot gold: up 0.1% to $US2,023.36 an ounce Brent crude: down 0.4% to $US76.70 a barrel Bitcoin: up 0.3% to $US27,641

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Telstra mobile phone outage
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you are a Telstra customer you may be facing some problems this morning making mobile phone calls, particularly in New South Wales and Queensland. Telstra says it's working urgently to fix the problems.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: S&P 500 movers and shakers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's what happened on the S & P 500 overnight, which ended flat overnight at 4,138. Pharmaceutical firm Catalent (-25.7 per cent) and Tyson Foods (-16.4 per cent) weighed on the benchmark index. But consumer staples, technology, financial and energy firms limited the losses.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Commonwealth Bank unveils $2.6 quarterly profit
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's been a big week for bank profits, and the Commonwealth Bank is the last big bank to announce its results. CBA March quarter profit: $2.6 billion unaudited net profit, up from $2.3 billion last year $2.6 billion cash profit, up 10 per cent from December quarter Net interest income down 2 per cent because of mortgage market competition Expenses up 7 per cent because of higher compensation costs $223 million loan impairments Cash earnings were better than expected as higher home and business lending offset squeezed profit margins because of tough competition for loans. CBA says there were "continued competitive pressure in home loan pricing and customers switching to higher yielding deposits." "Competition for home loans has remained intense in Australia and New Zealand." Home lending rose $6.9 billion over the quarter, household deposits were up $6.2 billion, and business lending increased by $2.6 billion. But troubled and impaired assets rose to $6.7 billion, up from $6.3 billion at the end of 2023. The bank says home loan arrears remain low at 0.44 per cent (+0.01 per cent), but consumer finance arrears increased during the quarter with personal loan (+ 0.14 per cent) and credit card (+0.05 per cent) arrears rising. "We expect to see further increases in arrears rates as the full effects of interest rate increases are borne by borrowers in the month's ahead," the bank said. CBA chief executive Matt Comyn says higher interest rates are hurting customers and he expects the economy to slow down. "Many of our customers are feeling the strain of higher interest rates and the rising cost of living," he said. "As higher interest rates impact the Australian economy in the period ahead, we expect economic growth to continue to moderate." "Despite the challenging global economic outlook, Australia is relatively well positioned given the strength of our banking system, the economic tailwinds from a recovery in population growth, and relatively high commodity prices."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: PwC boss departs amid tax scandal
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hi team, Before we get lost in Budget chat, let's not let pass up big news from last night. Boss steps down Tom Seymour, the CEO of consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), stepped down last night in the middle of a growing scandal. Here's the summary of the mind-blowing scandal, backed up by emails published as part of a Senate inqury. What happened The government asked a PwC tax expert to help it write laws to better tax multinational companies. That expert - Peter-John Collins - used the secret knowledge to help PwC create a system for those companies to avoid paying the new taxes. The company used the scheme to make money and win new clients, and then gloated about it. Booted It came to light when former partner Peter-John Collins was banned by the Tax Practitioners Board disqualified him for a two year period because he "did not act with integrity" and "failed to have in place adequate arrangements to manage conflicts of interest". Multinational companies sometimes use a complex and expensive process of 'profit-shifting' to take money they've made in higher-taxing countries like Australia to countries like Singapore and The Netherlands where company tax rates are lower. The process is legal, but controversial. Boss gone too Mr Seymour has attempted to minimise the scope of the people involved in the scandal. New documents revealed more people - including him - were aware of the information. (Some may not have been aware of the way in which the information about the new laws came to be in their possession - through Peter-John Collins breaching confidentiality provisions). As of last night, Mr Seymour is no longer CEO. Here's some of the statement. After discussion with the PwC Australia Board of Partners, Tom Seymour is stepping down as CEO, effective immediately. We have appointed our Assurance Leader, Kristin Stubbins, to serve as acting CEO. In the coming months a new CEO will be elected by the Partners. We agreed with Tom that this is in the best interests of the firm and our stakeholders. Given the federal government is the biggest client of PwC and there's currently a Senate hearing into use of consultants by the public service the timing couldn't have been worse.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Budget expected to deliver a small surplus
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: As I mentioned, the federal government is forecasting a small surplus of around $4 billion for 2022-23, the first surplus in 15 years. That would be a big turnaround from the $36.9 billion deficit forecast in October. However, more deficits are predicted in coming years amid rising welfare costs, debt interest payments, and increased costs from the National Disability Insurance Scheme, aged care, health, and defence. My colleague N icole Hegarty takes a look:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the budget?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Federal treasurer Jim Chalmers is expected to unveil a small surplus of $4 billion this financial year, the first surplus in 15 years, thanks to higher commodity prices. Other measures we know about include: $14.6 billion in cost of living relief Cheaper medicines JobSeeker payment increase expected New agency to make Australia a "renewable energy superpower" $11.3 billion to fund a 15 per cent rise for aged care workers $737 million to reduce vaping and smoking My colleague Gareth Hutchens takes a look at some of the major measures we know about:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Markets snapshot at 7:25am AEST
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX SPI 200: down 0.1% to 7,263 Australian dollar: down 0.1% to 67.77 US cents Dow Jones: down 0.2% to 33,619 S & P 500: flat at 4,138 Nasdaq Composite: up 0.2% to 12,257 FTSE: up 1% to 7,778 DAX: down 0.05% to 15,953 CAC 40: up 0.1% to 7,441 Spot gold: up 0.24% to $US2,021,39 Brent crude: up 1.8% to $US76.62 a barrel Bitcoin: down 0.2% to $US27,490

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US stocks take a breather, ASX SPI 200 slightly lower
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog. I'm Sue Lannin. Wall Street was lacklustre overnight after Friday's stellar performance thanks to a fall in the US unemployment rate, and Apple's better than expected quarterly earnings. Disappointing company profit reports weighed on the market with drug manufacturer Catalent (-25.7 per cent) tanking after warning of a $US400 million cut to its annual revenue and profit forecasts. Meanwhile, Tyson Foods slumped (-16.4 per cent) after making a loss over the second quarter. The Dow Jones index fell 0.2 per cent, the S & P 500 was flat, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2 per cent. And as Australian investors await tonight's federal budget, the ASX SPI 200 is down 0.1 per cent, indicating a slow start for the local share market. So join me today for all the markets news.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Live: ASX edges lower ahead of federal budget, CBA shares fall as bank says rate hikes hurting customers

CBA chief economist Stephen Halmarick says household spending is being hit by the higher cost of borrowing, with annual spending rates edging down. liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Household spending falls

children.content: The Commonwealth Bank's Household Spending Intentions survey fell 4.3 per cent in April, but that was partly because of fewer trading days because of the Easter and Anzac Day holidays.
The CBA says the index was led lower by reduced spending in home buying, health and fitness, transport, and household services.
Higher energy bills saw spending on utilities continue to climb, up by 7 per cent from April last year, the fastest since 2018.
CBA chief economist Stephen Halmarick says household spending is being hit by the higher cost of borrowing, with annual spending rates edging down.
"With the RBA increasing interest rates again in early May to 3.85 per cent we consider monetary policy to be highly restrictive," Mr Halmarick said.
"We continue to expect the lagged effect of higher interest rates to see household spending weaken as the year progresses."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The higher cost of living is hurting hip pockets. The Bureau of Statistics says consumers are cutting back, with the annual pace of household spending slowing down. Household spending rose 8.2 per cent over the year to March with spending increasing for both goods and services. It rose by nearly 12 per cent in February from a year ago, which was the weakest annual growth since March last year. The March increase was driven by spending on hotels, cafes and restaurants, which saw a 23 per cent increase in spending, and a 16 per cent rise in transport costs. ABS head of business indicators Robert Ewing said inflation was making prices more expensive and therefore increasing spending. "Rising prices are contributing to this growth," he said. "Services price inflation rose 6.1 per cent - it's largest rise since 2001 - and goods price inflation rose 7.6 per cent (over the year to March)."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Household spending growth slows

children.content: The higher cost of living is hurting hip pockets.
The Bureau of Statistics says consumers are cutting back, with the annual pace of household spending slowing down.

props.alt: Bar chart showing increases in household spending

children.content: ABS Household Spending
(ABS)
Household spending rose 8.2 per cent over the year to March with spending increasing for both goods and services.
It rose by nearly 12 per cent in February from a year ago, which was the weakest annual growth since March last year.
The March increase was driven by spending on hotels, cafes and restaurants, which saw a 23 per cent increase in spending, and a 16 per cent rise in transport costs.
ABS head of business indicators Robert Ewing said inflation was
making prices more expensive and therefore increasing spending.
"Rising prices are contributing to this growth," he said.
"Services price inflation rose 6.1 per cent - it's largest rise since 2001 - and goods price inflation rose 7.6 per cent (over the year to March)."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In a sign of the profit margin pressure from fierce competition among the big banks for mortgage borrowers, the Commonwealth Bank will stop offering $2000 cashbacks to new home loan customers. The other big banks have also been offering thousands of dollars in cashbacks to new mortgage borrowers, including those who are switching lenders for a better deal (refinancing). But the banks are starting to cut back on the deals with the CBA ceasing its offer from June 1. In addition, RateCity says over the past couple of months, CBA and the other big banks have been reducing discounts for new mortgage customers, including raising rates above Reserve Bank increases. "Cashback deals have become a hot potato for the banks, with CBA the first of the big four to drop them this year," said RateCity research director Sally Tindall. "The big banks have been at the centre of the refinancing storm over the last 12 months, throwing down competitive new customer discounts and cold hard cash to tempt borrowers to switch." "Now they are looking to take shelter from it." "The other big banks could well fold on their cashback deals in coming months, but if they're looking for growth, they've just been handed a reason to keep these deals on the table."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA ends cashbacks for mortgage customers

children.content: In a sign of the profit margin pressure from fierce competition among the big banks for mortgage borrowers, the Commonwealth Bank will stop offering $2000 cashbacks to new home loan customers.
The other big banks have also been offering thousands of dollars in cashbacks to new mortgage borrowers, including those who are switching lenders for a better deal (refinancing).
But the banks are starting to cut back on the deals with the CBA ceasing its offer from June 1.
In addition, RateCity says over the past couple of months, CBA and the other big banks have been reducing discounts for new mortgage customers, including raising rates above Reserve Bank increases.
"Cashback deals have become a hot potato for the banks, with CBA the first of the big four to drop them this year," said RateCity research director Sally Tindall.
"The big banks have been at the centre of the refinancing storm over the last 12 months, throwing down competitive new customer discounts and cold hard cash to tempt borrowers to switch."
"Now they are looking to take shelter from it."
"The other big banks could well fold on their cashback deals in coming months, but if they're looking for growth, they've just been handed a reason to keep these deals on the table."

props.alt: Table showing banks offering cashbacks for new mortgage customers

children.content: Bank cashback deals
(RateCity)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A battle between Qantas and the Transport Workers Union is being played out in the High Court in Canberra today over the outsourcing of 1700 ground staff. Qantas is appealing a ruling that found outsourcing ground crew jobs during the pandemic was illegal. The Federal Court has twice ruled in favour of the Transport Workers Union, who say the outsourcing decision breached the Fair Work Act. Qantas has told the High Court that it gave the union and workers the chance to come up with an alternative plan, but their proposed savings were dwarfed by the $100 million that outsourcing would achieve. The airline also said its decision was made at a time where workers had "less muscle" for industrial action because they weren't working. The Transport Workers Union told reporters today that half of the 1700 ground staff sacked by Qantas in 2020 are yet to find meaningful work, while a third are suffering mental distress. TWU national secretary, Michael Kaine, says Qantas should be compensating workers, instead of "spending eye watering amounts in legal warfare." "The Transport Workers Union, and we understand the Minister for Industrial Relations, will ask the court to dismiss the case." "In essence, we'll be saying that the Fair Work Act is designed to protect workers, allow them to exercise their workplace rights, not give companies like Qantas open slather to sack workers." Here's the background from High Court reporter Elizabeth Byrne.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas outsourcing battle before High Court

featuredLink.title: High Court to hear battle between Qantas and Transport Workers' Union over ground crew outsourcing

children.content: A battle between Qantas and the Transport Workers Union is being played out in the High Court in Canberra today over the outsourcing of 1700 ground staff.
Qantas is appealing a ruling that found outsourcing ground crew jobs during the pandemic was illegal.
The Federal Court has twice ruled in favour of the Transport Workers Union, who say the outsourcing decision breached the Fair Work Act.

Qantas has told the High Court that it gave the union and workers the chance to come up with an alternative plan, but their proposed savings were dwarfed by the $100 million that outsourcing would achieve.
The airline also said its decision was made at a time where workers had "less muscle" for industrial action because they weren't working.
The Transport Workers Union told reporters today that half of the 1700 ground staff sacked by Qantas in 2020 are yet to find meaningful work, while a third are suffering mental distress.
TWU national secretary, Michael Kaine, says Qantas should be compensating workers, instead of "spending eye watering amounts in legal warfare."
"The Transport Workers Union, and we understand the Minister for Industrial Relations, will ask the court to dismiss the case."
"In essence, we'll be saying that the Fair Work Act is designed to protect workers, allow them to exercise their workplace rights, not give companies like Qantas open slather to sack workers."
Here's the background from High Court reporter Elizabeth Byrne.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Northern Territory treasurer Eva Lawler has handed down the 2023 budget, predicting the territory will be back in surplus by the 2026-27 financial year. Spending on infrastructure is the big ticket item, with a record $2.1 billion spend next financial year, mainly on transport. The budget doesn't factor in potential revenue from big projects like fracking, which have not been given the green light. However, the forecast surplus relies on major projects going ahead, in particular, Santos' controversial Barossa gas project in the Timor Sea, which is being challenged by traditional owners. Here's more from the ABC's Matt Garrick.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NT forecasts budget surplus by 2026

featuredLink.title: NT budget sees record $2.1b infrastructure spend for roads, prisons, remote police station

children.content: The Northern Territory treasurer Eva Lawler has handed down the 2023 budget, predicting the territory will be back in surplus by the 2026-27 financial year.
Spending on infrastructure is the big ticket item, with a record $2.1 billion spend next financial year, mainly on transport.
The budget doesn't factor in potential revenue from big projects like fracking, which have not been given the green light.
However, the forecast surplus relies on major projects going ahead, in particular, Santos' controversial Barossa gas project in the Timor Sea, which is being challenged by traditional owners.
Here's more from the ABC's Matt Garrick.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's a quiet day on the markets ahead of tonight's federal budget. The ASX 200 index is down one quarter of a percentage point to 7,259 with nearly all sectors in the red. Financial stocks have recovered lost ground with the financials index slightly higher. The Commonwealth Bank -0.15 per cent) has come off its early lows after reporting a rise in quarterly profit, but warning of tougher times ahead because higher interest rates. Biotech Imugene (+6.5 per cent) is the best performer, while gold miner Silver Lake Resources (-4.7 per cent) is the worst performer on the ASX 200 index.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market in the red over lunchtime

children.content: It's a quiet day on the markets ahead of tonight's federal budget.
The ASX 200 index is down one quarter of a percentage point to 7,259 with nearly all sectors in the red.
Financial stocks have recovered lost ground with the financials index slightly higher.
The Commonwealth Bank -0.15 per cent) has come off its early lows after reporting a rise in quarterly profit, but warning of tougher times ahead because higher interest rates.
Biotech Imugene (+6.5 per cent) is the best performer, while gold miner Silver Lake Resources (-4.7 per cent) is the worst performer on the ASX 200 index.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's more signs of the strain that higher interest rates are putting on households, with people buying less but paying higher prices. The latest quarterly data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics shows that retail sales volumes fell 0.6 per cent over the first few months of the year to $96.17 billion, following a 0.3 per cent fall over the December quarter. ABS head of retail statistics Ben Dorber says retail sales volumes dropped as the higher cost of living pressures weighed on household spending. “Outside of the COVID-19 pandemic period, this is the largest fall in retail sales volumes since the September quarter 2009,” Mr Dorber said. "Retail prices rose for the sixth straight quarter, but price growth this quarter is the smallest since September 2021." That was because of discounts on clothing and large household items like furniture and electronic goods. Food prices went up, and sales at cafes, restaurants, and takeaway food services rose, boosted by the return of cultural and sporting events.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Retail sales volumes fall over March quarter

children.content: There's more signs of the strain that higher interest rates are putting on households, with people buying less but paying higher prices.

The latest quarterly data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics shows that retail sales volumes fell 0.6 per cent over the first few months of the year to $96.17 billion, following a 0.3 per cent fall over the December quarter.
ABS head of retail statistics Ben Dorber says retail sales volumes dropped as the higher cost of living pressures weighed on household spending.
“Outside of the COVID-19 pandemic period, this is the largest fall in retail sales volumes since the September quarter 2009,” Mr Dorber said.
"Retail prices rose for the sixth straight quarter, but price growth this quarter is the smallest since September 2021."
That was because of discounts on clothing and large household items like furniture and electronic goods.
Food prices went up, and sales at cafes, restaurants, and takeaway food services rose, boosted by the return of cultural and sporting events.

props.alt: bar graph showing retail sales industries over March quarter

children.content: March quarter retail sales
(ABS)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you think those comments from shadow treasurer Angus Taylor that a "drover's dog" could have delivered a budget surplus this year sound familiar, you would be right. They were used by then opposition leader Bill Hayden during a Labor Party leadership spill in February 1983. Mr Hayden resigned as party leader and then shadow industrial relations minister Bob Hawke was elected as leader. Afterwards Mr Hayden said "a drover's dog could lead the Labor Party to victory, the way the country is." The Labor party won the election and Mr Hawke became prime minister. So Mr Taylor's inspiration comes from the Labor Party! Here's more on the budget and the "drover's dog" from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The 'drover's dog' and the budget surplus

children.content: If you think those comments from shadow treasurer Angus Taylor that a "drover's dog" could have delivered a budget surplus this year sound familiar, you would be right.
They were used by then opposition leader Bill Hayden during a Labor Party leadership spill in February 1983.
Mr Hayden resigned as party leader and then shadow industrial relations minister Bob Hawke was elected as leader.
Afterwards Mr Hayden said "a drover's dog could lead the Labor Party to victory, the way the country is."
The Labor party won the election and Mr Hawke became prime minister.
So Mr Taylor's inspiration comes from the Labor Party!
Here's more on the budget and the "drover's dog" from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan.

Biotech Imugene (+4.4 per cent) is the best performer in the ASX 200, while farm business Elders (-4.6 per cent) is the worst performer.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's been a big week for bank profits, and the Commonwealth Bank is the last big bank to announce its results. CBA March quarter profit: $2.6 billion unaudited net profit, up from $2.3 billion last year $2.6 billion cash profit, up 10 per cent from December quarter Net interest income down 2 per cent because of mortgage market competition Expenses up 7 per cent because of higher compensation costs $223 million loan impairments Cash earnings were better than expected as higher home and business lending offset squeezed profit margins because of tough competition for loans. CBA says there were "continued competitive pressure in home loan pricing and customers switching to higher yielding deposits." "Competition for home loans has remained intense in Australia and New Zealand." Home lending rose $6.9 billion over the quarter, household deposits were up $6.2 billion, and business lending increased by $2.6 billion. But troubled and impaired assets rose to $6.7 billion, up from $6.3 billion at the end of 2023. The bank says home loan arrears remain low at 0.44 per cent (+0.01 per cent), but consumer finance arrears increased during the quarter with personal loan (+ 0.14 per cent) and credit card (+0.05 per cent) arrears rising. "We expect to see further increases in arrears rates as the full effects of interest rate increases are borne by borrowers in the month's ahead," the bank said. CBA chief executive Matt Comyn says higher interest rates are hurting customers and he expects the economy to slow down. "Many of our customers are feeling the strain of higher interest rates and the rising cost of living," he said. "As higher interest rates impact the Australian economy in the period ahead, we expect economic growth to continue to moderate." "Despite the challenging global economic outlook, Australia is relatively well positioned given the strength of our banking system, the economic tailwinds from a recovery in population growth, and relatively high commodity prices."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Commonwealth Bank unveils $2.6 quarterly profit

children.content: It's been a big week for bank profits, and the Commonwealth Bank is the last big bank to announce its results.
CBA March quarter profit:
$2.6 billion unaudited net profit, up from $2.3 billion last year
$2.6 billion cash profit, up 10 per cent from December quarter
Net interest income down 2 per cent because of mortgage market competition
Expenses up 7 per cent because of higher compensation costs
$223 million loan impairments
Cash earnings were better than expected as higher home and business lending offset squeezed profit margins because of tough competition for loans.
CBA says there were "continued competitive pressure in home loan pricing and customers switching to higher yielding deposits."
"Competition for home loans has remained intense in Australia and New Zealand."
Home lending rose $6.9 billion over the quarter, household deposits were up $6.2 billion, and business lending increased by $2.6 billion.
But troubled and impaired assets rose to $6.7 billion, up from $6.3 billion at the end of 2023.
The bank says home loan arrears remain low at 0.44 per cent (+0.01 per cent), but consumer finance arrears increased during the quarter with personal loan (+ 0.14 per cent)
and credit card (+0.05 per cent) arrears rising.
"We expect to see further increases in arrears rates as the full effects of interest rate increases are borne by borrowers in the month's ahead," the bank said.
CBA chief executive Matt Comyn says higher interest rates are hurting customers and he expects the economy to slow down.
"Many of our customers are feeling the strain of higher interest rates and the rising cost of living," he said.
"As higher interest rates impact the Australian economy in the period ahead, we expect economic growth to continue to moderate."

"Despite the challenging global economic outlook, Australia is relatively well positioned given the strength of our banking system, the economic tailwinds from a recovery in population growth, and relatively high commodity prices."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hi team, Before we get lost in Budget chat, let's not let pass up big news from last night. Boss steps down Tom Seymour, the CEO of consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), stepped down last night in the middle of a growing scandal. Here's the summary of the mind-blowing scandal, backed up by emails published as part of a Senate inqury. What happened The government asked a PwC tax expert to help it write laws to better tax multinational companies. That expert - Peter-John Collins - used the secret knowledge to help PwC create a system for those companies to avoid paying the new taxes. The company used the scheme to make money and win new clients, and then gloated about it. Booted It came to light when former partner Peter-John Collins was banned by the Tax Practitioners Board disqualified him for a two year period because he "did not act with integrity" and "failed to have in place adequate arrangements to manage conflicts of interest". Multinational companies sometimes use a complex and expensive process of 'profit-shifting' to take money they've made in higher-taxing countries like Australia to countries like Singapore and The Netherlands where company tax rates are lower. The process is legal, but controversial. Boss gone too Mr Seymour has attempted to minimise the scope of the people involved in the scandal. New documents revealed more people - including him - were aware of the information. (Some may not have been aware of the way in which the information about the new laws came to be in their possession - through Peter-John Collins breaching confidentiality provisions). As of last night, Mr Seymour is no longer CEO. Here's some of the statement. After discussion with the PwC Australia Board of Partners, Tom Seymour is stepping down as CEO, effective immediately. We have appointed our Assurance Leader, Kristin Stubbins, to serve as acting CEO. In the coming months a new CEO will be elected by the Partners. We agreed with Tom that this is in the best interests of the firm and our stakeholders. Given the federal government is the biggest client of PwC and there's currently a Senate hearing into use of consultants by the public service the timing couldn't have been worse.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC boss departs amid tax scandal

featuredLink.title: The ATO says a confidentiality breach at PwC could have cost the government millions in tax

children.content: Hi team,
Before we get lost in Budget chat, let's not let pass up big news from last night.
Boss steps down
Tom Seymour, the CEO of consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), stepped down last night in the middle of a growing scandal.
Here's the summary of the mind-blowing scandal, backed up by emails published as part of a Senate inqury.
What happened

The government asked a PwC tax expert to help it write laws to better tax multinational companies. That expert - Peter-John Collins - used the secret knowledge to help PwC create a system for those companies to
avoid
paying the new taxes.
The company used the scheme to make money and win new clients, and then gloated about it.
Booted
It came to light when former partner Peter-John Collins was banned by the Tax Practitioners Board
disqualified him for a two year period
because he "did not act with integrity" and "failed to have in place adequate arrangements to manage conflicts of interest".

Multinational companies sometimes use a complex and expensive process of 'profit-shifting' to take money they've made in higher-taxing countries like Australia to countries like Singapore and The Netherlands where company tax rates are lower. The process is legal, but controversial.
Boss gone too
Mr Seymour has attempted to minimise the scope of the people involved in the scandal. New documents revealed more people - including him - were aware of the information.
(Some may not have been aware of the way in which the information about the new laws came to be in their possession - through Peter-John Collins breaching confidentiality provisions).
As of last night, Mr Seymour is no longer CEO. Here's some of the statement.

After discussion with the PwC Australia Board of Partners, Tom Seymour is stepping down as CEO, effective immediately. We have appointed our Assurance Leader, Kristin Stubbins, to serve as acting CEO. In the coming months a new CEO will be elected by the Partners. We agreed with Tom that this is in the best interests of the firm and our stakeholders.
Given the federal government is the biggest client of PwC and there's currently a Senate hearing into
use of consultants by the public service
the timing couldn't have been worse.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As I mentioned, the federal government is forecasting a small surplus of around $4 billion for 2022-23, the first surplus in 15 years. That would be a big turnaround from the $36.9 billion deficit forecast in October. However, more deficits are predicted in coming years amid rising welfare costs, debt interest payments, and increased costs from the National Disability Insurance Scheme, aged care, health, and defence. My colleague N icole Hegarty takes a look:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Budget expected to deliver a small surplus

featuredLink.title: Federal budget to forecast first surplus in 15 years

That would be a big turnaround from the $36.9 billion deficit forecast in October.

However, more deficits are predicted in coming years amid rising welfare costs, debt interest payments, and increased costs from the National Disability Insurance Scheme, aged care, health, and defence.
My colleague N
icole Hegarty

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog. I'm Sue Lannin. Wall Street was lacklustre overnight after Friday's stellar performance thanks to a fall in the US unemployment rate, and Apple's better than expected quarterly earnings. Disappointing company profit reports weighed on the market with drug manufacturer Catalent (-25.7 per cent) tanking after warning of a $US400 million cut to its annual revenue and profit forecasts. Meanwhile, Tyson Foods slumped (-16.4 per cent) after making a loss over the second quarter. The Dow Jones index fell 0.2 per cent, the S & P 500 was flat, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2 per cent. And as Australian investors await tonight's federal budget, the ASX SPI 200 is down 0.1 per cent, indicating a slow start for the local share market. So join me today for all the markets news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US stocks take a breather, ASX SPI 200 slightly lower

children.content: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog.
I'm Sue Lannin.
Wall Street was lacklustre overnight after Friday's stellar performance thanks to a fall in the US unemployment rate, and Apple's better than expected quarterly earnings.
Disappointing company profit reports weighed on the market with drug manufacturer
Catalent
(-25.7 per cent) tanking after warning of a $US400 million cut to its annual revenue and profit forecasts.
Meanwhile,
Tyson Foods
slumped (-16.4 per cent) after making a loss over the second quarter.
The Dow Jones index fell 0.2 per cent, the S
P 500 was flat, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2 per cent.
And as Australian investors await tonight's federal budget, the ASX SPI 200 is down 0.1 per cent, indicating a slow start for the local share market.
So join me today for all the markets news.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The higher cost of living is hurting hip pockets. The Bureau of Statistics says consumers are cutting back, with the annual pace of household spending slowing down. Household spending rose 8.2 per cent over the year to March with spending increasing for both goods and services. It rose by nearly 12 per cent in February from a year ago, which was the weakest annual growth since March last year. The March increase was driven by spending on hotels, cafes and restaurants, which saw a 23 per cent increase in spending, and a 16 per cent rise in transport costs. ABS head of business indicators Robert Ewing said inflation was making prices more expensive and therefore increasing spending. "Rising prices are contributing to this growth," he said. "Services price inflation rose 6.1 per cent - it's largest rise since 2001 - and goods price inflation rose 7.6 per cent (over the year to March)."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Household spending growth slows

children.content: The higher cost of living is hurting hip pockets.
The Bureau of Statistics says consumers are cutting back, with the annual pace of household spending slowing down.

props.alt: Bar chart showing increases in household spending

children.content: ABS Household Spending
(ABS)
Household spending rose 8.2 per cent over the year to March with spending increasing for both goods and services.
It rose by nearly 12 per cent in February from a year ago, which was the weakest annual growth since March last year.
The March increase was driven by spending on hotels, cafes and restaurants, which saw a 23 per cent increase in spending, and a 16 per cent rise in transport costs.
ABS head of business indicators Robert Ewing said inflation was
making prices more expensive and therefore increasing spending.
"Rising prices are contributing to this growth," he said.
"Services price inflation rose 6.1 per cent - it's largest rise since 2001 - and goods price inflation rose 7.6 per cent (over the year to March)."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In a sign of the profit margin pressure from fierce competition among the big banks for mortgage borrowers, the Commonwealth Bank will stop offering $2000 cashbacks to new home loan customers. The other big banks have also been offering thousands of dollars in cashbacks to new mortgage borrowers, including those who are switching lenders for a better deal (refinancing). But the banks are starting to cut back on the deals with the CBA ceasing its offer from June 1. In addition, RateCity says over the past couple of months, CBA and the other big banks have been reducing discounts for new mortgage customers, including raising rates above Reserve Bank increases. "Cashback deals have become a hot potato for the banks, with CBA the first of the big four to drop them this year," said RateCity research director Sally Tindall. "The big banks have been at the centre of the refinancing storm over the last 12 months, throwing down competitive new customer discounts and cold hard cash to tempt borrowers to switch." "Now they are looking to take shelter from it." "The other big banks could well fold on their cashback deals in coming months, but if they're looking for growth, they've just been handed a reason to keep these deals on the table."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA ends cashbacks for mortgage customers

children.content: In a sign of the profit margin pressure from fierce competition among the big banks for mortgage borrowers, the Commonwealth Bank will stop offering $2000 cashbacks to new home loan customers.
The other big banks have also been offering thousands of dollars in cashbacks to new mortgage borrowers, including those who are switching lenders for a better deal (refinancing).
But the banks are starting to cut back on the deals with the CBA ceasing its offer from June 1.
In addition, RateCity says over the past couple of months, CBA and the other big banks have been reducing discounts for new mortgage customers, including raising rates above Reserve Bank increases.
"Cashback deals have become a hot potato for the banks, with CBA the first of the big four to drop them this year," said RateCity research director Sally Tindall.
"The big banks have been at the centre of the refinancing storm over the last 12 months, throwing down competitive new customer discounts and cold hard cash to tempt borrowers to switch."
"Now they are looking to take shelter from it."
"The other big banks could well fold on their cashback deals in coming months, but if they're looking for growth, they've just been handed a reason to keep these deals on the table."

props.alt: Table showing banks offering cashbacks for new mortgage customers

children.content: Bank cashback deals
(RateCity)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A battle between Qantas and the Transport Workers Union is being played out in the High Court in Canberra today over the outsourcing of 1700 ground staff. Qantas is appealing a ruling that found outsourcing ground crew jobs during the pandemic was illegal. The Federal Court has twice ruled in favour of the Transport Workers Union, who say the outsourcing decision breached the Fair Work Act. Qantas has told the High Court that it gave the union and workers the chance to come up with an alternative plan, but their proposed savings were dwarfed by the $100 million that outsourcing would achieve. The airline also said its decision was made at a time where workers had "less muscle" for industrial action because they weren't working. The Transport Workers Union told reporters today that half of the 1700 ground staff sacked by Qantas in 2020 are yet to find meaningful work, while a third are suffering mental distress. TWU national secretary, Michael Kaine, says Qantas should be compensating workers, instead of "spending eye watering amounts in legal warfare." "The Transport Workers Union, and we understand the Minister for Industrial Relations, will ask the court to dismiss the case." "In essence, we'll be saying that the Fair Work Act is designed to protect workers, allow them to exercise their workplace rights, not give companies like Qantas open slather to sack workers." Here's the background from High Court reporter Elizabeth Byrne.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas outsourcing battle before High Court

featuredLink.title: High Court to hear battle between Qantas and Transport Workers' Union over ground crew outsourcing

children.content: A battle between Qantas and the Transport Workers Union is being played out in the High Court in Canberra today over the outsourcing of 1700 ground staff.
Qantas is appealing a ruling that found outsourcing ground crew jobs during the pandemic was illegal.
The Federal Court has twice ruled in favour of the Transport Workers Union, who say the outsourcing decision breached the Fair Work Act.

Qantas has told the High Court that it gave the union and workers the chance to come up with an alternative plan, but their proposed savings were dwarfed by the $100 million that outsourcing would achieve.
The airline also said its decision was made at a time where workers had "less muscle" for industrial action because they weren't working.
The Transport Workers Union told reporters today that half of the 1700 ground staff sacked by Qantas in 2020 are yet to find meaningful work, while a third are suffering mental distress.
TWU national secretary, Michael Kaine, says Qantas should be compensating workers, instead of "spending eye watering amounts in legal warfare."
"The Transport Workers Union, and we understand the Minister for Industrial Relations, will ask the court to dismiss the case."
"In essence, we'll be saying that the Fair Work Act is designed to protect workers, allow them to exercise their workplace rights, not give companies like Qantas open slather to sack workers."
Here's the background from High Court reporter Elizabeth Byrne.
